message: I like the idea of a web app for the accessibility too.  It probably all depends on whether convore takes off - if there aren't other interesting groups to talk with then I could see there being fewer participants in the chats here.

I'm thinking I should rephrase this. Not planning on getting rid of IRC any time soon. Just wondering if convore would be better for real time discussions as it's more accessible through a web browser. I *am* worried about fragmenting the discussion to much between the mailing list, convore and IRC though.
How is the IRC?  I notice that the google group has 4 or 5 conversations per month.  Is IRC a lot more chatty?
A lot of people appreciate that IRC is an open-protocol where as convore is a website. Though the convore API is setup for people to build apps around if they want.

The google group hadn't really picked up, then a few weeks ago it seemed to really burst with traffic. I like the idea of a google group for long for discussions and using irc or convore for real-time chat.
You can star stuff here too
I would honestly use convore more than IRC. I live in my browser. Convore seems to be the best of IRC meets Google Groups.
Starting to feel some love for Convore. It's definately more accessable than IRC. Stars and mentions are handy too.
Convore is nice, fast, and looks great. Plus you can sign in via Twitter. No nicks.
I appreciate the persistence of Convore. It was nice to be able to go back and read the messages from last night. Being able to star stuff is handy.
If you are still taking votes... Convore seems awesome and we should stick with this.
I guess I can see the place for both Convore and IRC. So don't worry, I'll try to haunt both. Convore seems like a mailing list (topics), but at twitter speeds (short, chat-like). I like!
+1 convore
This thing doesn't suck as bad as I thought it would. I love IRC, but I hate having to be connected to it all the time to be in a convo. +1 convore.
@RyanOnRails those are pretty much my thoughts as well. The Convore API also seems solid if we ever feel the need to backup the conversations later.
I enjoy how conversations on Convore are saved so you can easily come back and check unread messages.
Plus you can delete a post when you've made a spelling mistake and re-post it.
I think convore is a good solution and seems to be getting good uptake, but it kills me to add another communication tool to my daily tool box. :(
@MarkBennett thanks but I use an iPhone :D found it during the BuildNight. I was listening I swear :D
and it is available on the iPhone. Not sure about Android
@djchrisjohn There's an android app called Convorsation made by @EisFrei, but it's still in dev. It's got a group if you want to follow it https://convore.com/convorsation/.
Wow, that's actually a really easy API
hmm
I'm disappointed that the top search result for convore irc gateway is your tweet @markbennett
All of the irc would end up in one topic though, which might keep it more organised.
@Blaze sounds like the perfect hackup project to me. :)
Yeah, the API is one of the reasons I'm not totally against using Convore.
We could use something like this to monitor convore... https://github.com/fx/convore

I actually like the idea of being able to # tag or somehow reply to threads back from IRC.  Otherwise I can see the workflow; sitting in IRC, see someone post a question which you can answer, then having to go log into Convore to reply to it. :(
@MarkBennett that makes better sense

Good point @RyanOnRails. I guess an easier of the two would be to haul in convore topics into IRC. Going the other way from IRC maybe there could be a way to add a hash tag to you IRC message that would link back to the convore topic. Hmm, that's starting to sound complicated
So... hackup idea? I'm game
So essentially we'd run a bot on the IRC server which would past the results in here? Or.. The other way? How would we categorize it into the "posts" on the server.

A bot which slurps up posts to the irc channel and posts them in a topic here called "#yegrb on irc.freenode.net" would make sense to me. It would have to include people's irc handles in the posts because it would look like it was posting everything itself. To post back to irc it would do the opposite and post everyone's convore handles in it's messages.
And people could always use a real irc client if they want a better experience.
Yea, that's a great idea Mark. This looks promising http://rubyforge.org/frs/?group_id=1784
Better yet: http://ruby-toolbox.com/categories/irc_bots.html
http://github.com/ichverstehe/isaac and https://github.com/injekt/cinch look promising

I was thinking only the one topic would sync. So if you want to talk to the people in IRC through convore you have to use an irc topic. And everything that's said in that topic would post to IRC, while everything said in IRC would post to the topic.

Yea, there needs to be a back and forth. Essentially it would just be 1 massive post on this convore thing, and if i reply it goes to IRC, and if someone says something in IRC it will come into convore.
I wonder how convore will handle a massive topic.  Hopefully it won't load the entire thread any time you view it, but that's kind of what it looks like.
@x0nic that's a really good idea!

If you wanted to get someone's attention on Convore from IRC I think you can just include their convore name with the @ in front of it and it will show up in their mentions. So if I were to say, "Hi @benzittlau on Convore" in the #yegrb IRC channel the bot would post that message to the IRC topic in the YEGRB group and you'd see it. You'd need to manually use their IRC nick to reply to them.
@benzittlau yeah, that's probably a valid question. you'd think Convore might alter their pages/API to stream older messages though. I'll have to take a look and find a long topic.
You could create a new topic, every time the topic in IRC changed.
Whoa,  @x0nic that's a badass idea.
It looks like it does (no dynamic loading). Can I chime in about the clunky scrolling again 8)?
It would be more work, but I think we need to go the other way
I'd expect it would be a good chance to play with EventMachine
a /list would show you all the topics of the groups you are part of, etc
the bridge would be an IRC server that you connect to
then the server would auto-join you to channels matching the topics you are part of
Before everyone gets too carried away here, I should also point out that there is a very good Freenode web client. http://webchat.freenode.net/
I for one think the IRC integration isn't all that important to me; but then again I've fallen out of the habit of IRC as of late.
@SeanOuimet Ditto. I used to be in IRC all the time. But I've gotta agree with @darkhelmetlive, If I can have 1 place to access all my stuff (browser) I'm all about that.
I've yet to see a good gopher:// interface in a browser, so until then I'll need more then just my browser!  #myunixbearditches
@benzittlau looks like Convore does only load a set amount of conversation before hiding older messages. http://img6.imagebanana.com/img/uqh0j2yj/Workspace1_005.png
embedded images; that's cool
ooooo, embedded images + load previous messages = sexy time.
